Halima is 27 years old and is a married woman with 2 children, ages 5 and 3 years old. She and her husband also take care of 1 other person, age 45 years old. Halima owns a small shop, which she started in 2006. Everyday, she works from 8am to 9pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $190 from her sales.

In the past,Halima has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: to buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Pablo Emilio

texts.es:
Mr. Pablo Emilio M. N. is the man wearing a red shirt and blue cap. He is a 63-year-old man from the city of Bluefields. He is married to Mrs. Virginia López, with whom his has 3 adult kids who have received an education thanks to the income generated from Mr. M.’s business. He has been a photographer for over 45 years. His customers are people of all ages who prefer him because he gives specialized in-home services. He currently needs to buy 30 boxes of Polaroid film—at $16.00 per box—and 65 rolls of film—at $6.00 per roll. With this investment, he will be able to meet his customers’ demands.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

El Sr. Pablo Emilio M. N. es el que se encuentra vestido con camisa roja y gorra azul, es originario de la ciudad de Bluefields, tiene 63 años de edad, esta casado con la Sra. Virginia López ambos tienen 3 hijos mayores de edad, que han obtenido sus estudios por el ingreso del negocio del Sr. M. quien tiene más de 45 años de ser fotógrafo, sus clientes son hombres y mujeres de todas las edades que lo prefieren por brindar servicio especializado y a domicilio, en estos momentos necesita comprar 30 cajas de polaroid a $16.00 dólares cada caja y 65 rollo películas a $6.00 dólares cada rollo con esta inversión podrá satisfacer sus demandas.

loans.use: Purchase 30 boxes of Polaroid film and 65 rolls of film

loans.name: Veronica's Mapinduzi Group

texts.en:
Veronica is 31 years old and is a married woman with 3 children, ages 13,10 and 2 years old. Veronica sells clothes. She started in 2008. Every day, she works from 6am to 10pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $20 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business.She will share this loan with her subgroup members, Rehema and Gudila, who have a shop and sell vegetables.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business.

loans.name: Vitalina

texts.en:
Vitalina T., 34, is married with 3 children. She has many years' experience in the taro/banana business. She sells to the village people and general public 3 days per week.

Vitalina has 3 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (about US$145). SPBD loans are Vitalina’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Education and home improvement, and also her church activities are important to her. Even though she's the one who is applying for the loan, really her husband did all the hard work to make sure the buisness will succcessful.

loans.use: Purchase chemicals, back sprayer, bush knives, shovel

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina I., 55, is married with 7 children and lives at Luatuanuu, Samoa. She has 2 years of experience in the pig farm business. She sells to the villagers and general public 5 days per week.

Rosalina has had 2 previous loans with SPBD. She will use this loan to purchase fencing and feed for her pigs. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 200 Tala (US$83). SPBD loans are Rosalina’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To buy fencing and pig feed

loans.name: Salina

texts.en: Salina is 32 years old. She is a wife and mother of three kids. Currently, the kids are in school. She has been sewing for eight years. She is a specialist in female clothing. Her skills and designs are excellent. She sews various kinds of styles that give her customers new looks, like kaba and slit, wedding dresses, funeral clothes, etc. She also sells sachet water as a distributor to give her extra income to support her family. She wants to use the loan to buy increased supplies of sewing materials like linen, threads, thimbles, etc. to increase her output and efficiency, as well as sachet water. She hopes to increase her savings to provide her children with a quality education. She is a member of the community group called "Nyame yie Group". In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral and provide support to each other to repay the loans.

loans.use: To buy increased supplies of sewing material

loans.name: Idigul

texts.ru: Нурова Идигуль проживает в городе Норак. Работает в том же городе. Занимается бизнесом. Торгует продуктами питания уже пять лет. Бизнес приносит доход ,который позволяет ей обеспечивать свою семью. Она одна кормит  и обеспечивает троих детей. Муж ничем не занимается , поэтому она очень много работает. Планирует получить кредит для увеличения товарооборота. Это поможет расширить бизнес. Погасить кредит планирует в течении 10 месяцев.
texts.en:
Idigul N. lives in the city of Norak. She works in the same city, running a business. For the last five years she has been selling various foods. The income coming from the business enables her to support her family. She alone raises and provides for her three children. Her husband is jobless, so she works a lot. She decided to apply for a loan to increase sales. It will help her expand the business. The loan will be repaid over 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase Sales

loans.name: John

texts.en: John T. K. is a 49-year-old businessman. He is married with five children and very dedicated to his work. He owns and operates a grocery shop and sells items like rice, evaporated milk, canned foods and drinks, assorted cooking oil, washing powder, toilet soaps, candies, biscuits etc. in the local market of Nankese, in Koforidua. John supports his family with proceeds from his business. He wants to use the loan to buy supplies in bulk to expand his business. John hopes to save more towards his children's education. He belongs to the community group called 'Nyame mma Trust Group'. The group members guarantee and support one another to repay their loans on time.

loans.use: To buy store supplies in bulk

loans.name: Maribel

texts.es: Maribel tiene 22 años, es madre soltera de un niño de 3 años de edad. Desde hace 6 años, se dedica a la compra y venta de cereales de la zona, como la quinua, cañihua, etc.  Vende los cereales de forma ambulatoria, por la plaza de armas del distrito, ofreciendo sus productos a los transeúntes, usualmente sale a vender desde las 8 de la mañana hasta promediar las 3 de la tarde, ya que también debe ocuparse del cuidado de su pequeño hijo. Lo más difícil es tener que salir a trabajar con su pequeño, desdoblándose entre el trabajo de venta y el de mamá. El motivo del esfuerzo de esta madre es su pequeño hijo de 3 años, desea que tenga las mejores oportunidades de alcanzar un futuro mejor. Con el dinero del préstamo comprará más de sus cereales, aumentando así sus ingresos económicos.  En el futuro, Maribel quiere tener una pequeña tienda de abarrotes que pueda administrar desde su casa.
texts.en:
Maribel is 22 years old, she is a single mother with a 3 year old son. For 6 years she has been buying and selling local grains, like quinoa and cañihua (which is a similar grain to quinoa local to the region), etc. She sells these grains around the 'plaza de armas', a square in the district, offering her products to passers-by. She normally goes out to sell at 8am until 3pm, as she must also look after her young son. The most difficult thing is going out to work with her son, as she must divide herself between being a saleswoman and a Mum. The motive for this Mum's hard work is her young 3 year old son, as she wants him to have the best opportunities to have a better future. With the loan she will buy more grains, thereby increasing her income. In the future, Maribel wants to have a small grocery store that she can look after from home.


Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase the amount of grains that she sells/Incrementar la cantidad de cereales que vende.

loans.name: San Juan Bautista De Cayara Group

texts.en:
The San Juan Bautista D. Cayara Village Bank is part of FINCA Peru’s Project Wari, an effort to bring micro-loans to rural communities in central Peru. The group is maD. up of 18 members from the Ayacucho region’s Cayara community, who are together requesting loans of $2025 (6200 PEN). The town is located an hour from Huancapi District, on the highway to Southern Ayacucho. The community has three different elevations: a low part suited to growing fruit, a middle ground suited to growing grains, and an elevated section suited to growing tubers, namely potatoes.

Dina, Reyna Marta, and Eufemia are three members of the San Juan Bautista D. Cayara Village Bank.

Dina is married but separated with two children who are 6 and 12 years old and currently attend school. Dina sells dry goods from a small stO., and would like to expand her businesses and sell ground grains. She is requesting a loan of $65 (200 PEN), which she plans to use to buy grains, whole and ground, to bring to the Canaria Mine to sell. She is grateful to work with FINCA; she says it provides a good opportunity to save and to continue to expand her business. Her goals for the future are to proviD. her children with a good education, improve her business, and get ahead in life. She is saving for her children’s education.

Reyna Marta is married and has three children who are 7, 9, and 12 years old. Reyna sells sweets outsiD. several local schools. She also sells lunch to teachers and to workers who are installing an irrigation canal in her community. She is requesting a loan of $65 (200 PEN) to buy mO. sweets to sell and start running her lunch counter from a kiosk in the town’s main plaza. Reyna’s dream is to move her family to a city with mO. opportunities and open up a business in the city of Huamanga. FINCA has helped her save money for herself and for her children. Like Dina, Reyna is saving up for her children’s education. She says her husband plans to start saving, too.

Eufemia lives with her partner and their three children, who are 1, 4, and 9 years old and are all in school. She is involved in Cayara’s local government, and also runs a small stO. and sells household supplies. She is requesting a loan of $200 (600 PEN), which she will use to buy mO. products for her stO. and to help jump-start her savings. Eufemia says that when she first heard that FINCA was coming to Cayara she didn’t believe it, but it did indeed come, and is helping community members to save, which she likes. Eufemia says that her businesses are doing well, and she knows she will get ahead in life. Eufemia dreams that her children will go to college someday. She wants to leave her village to proviD. her children with a better education. Like Dina and Reyna, she is saving up for her children’s education.

loans.use: Buy grains, buy sweets and open a lunch counter, and buy household supplies to sell

loans.name: Rosas Blancas Group

texts.es: El grupo de las "Rosas Blancas" esta representado por la señora Josefina, se encuentra conformado por 9 mujeres y 2 varones que se reúnen constantemente para organizarse y para verificar como  se invierten los fondos otorgados. Son gente responsable y honesta, ellas se dedican al comercio de diferentes productos como ser ropa, cosméticos, peluches, celulares y a la venta de comida criolla y entre los varones a la fundición de metales. En vista de que la competencia para el sector comercio es muy grande ellas necesitan  incrementar su capital de trabajo para en cierta manera disminuir el precio y poder vender mas cantidad o en menor tiempo y así tendrán mayor flujo de dinero para responder a la demanda del mercado y a la mejora de la calidad de vida de sus familias. La mayoría de los socios (as) tienen experiencia en grupos solidarios por lo que conoces el modo de trabajo y también la responsabilidad que se necesita para corresponder con la ayuda que le brindada la fundación Agrocapital.
texts.en:
The group "Rosas Blancas" is lead by Josefina C. A.. It is made up of 9 women and 2 men who meet regularly to organize grant money and determine how they ought to invest it. They are honest and responsible people. The women trade in various products, such as clothing, cosmetics, stuffed animals, and cellphones. They also sell traditional Latin American food. The men work in the smelting and casting of metals. Since there is significant competition for business in the commercial sector, the women need to increase the money they have to work with, so that they may stably lower their prices and enable themselves to sell a greater quantity of goods in less time. By doing this, they will create a greater flow of incoming money, which will allow them to better respond to market demands and to improve quality of life for themselves and their families. Most of the group members have previous experience with group loans, so they are familiar with group work and know how to take advantage of the opportunity they are being offered by Fundacion AgroCapital.

Translated from Spanish by Kevin Lenhart, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Capital for Business Enhancement

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Hồng năm nay 25 tuổiChị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2001. Hiện nay công việc đem lại nguồn thu nhập chủ yếu cho gia đình chị  là chăn nuôi và lương thợ xây của chồng với mức thu nhập 4.000.000đ/ tháng. Để mở rộng chăn nuôi thời gian tới chị Hồng mong muốn được vay 15.000.000đ về đầu tư sửa sang chuồng trại và mua thêm lợn về nuôi.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi H. is 25 years old. She has joined TYM Fund (Kiva Partner in Vietnam) since 2001. Currently her main family's source of income comes from raising animals and her husband's wage from construction work, totalling 4,000,000 VND per month (about 233 USD per month). In order to expand her farm, Mrs. H. wants to borrow 15,000,000 VND (or 875 USD) to fix the farm and buy more pigs.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising

loans.name: Dembagnouma Group

texts.fr:
En majorité des femmes mariées, les membres du groupe Dembagnouma ont une moyenne d’âge de 26 ans et de 3 enfants. Elles vivent  dans de familles conjugales traditionnelles élargies avec les époux, sœurs et frères. Elles résident dans le village de Coni sous préfecture de Fana région de Koulikoro république du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des relations commerciales. En effet elles exercent toutes le commerce de céréales.
Dans le souci de développer leur commerce ces femmes ont intégré le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). Tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés. 
Les membres du groupe comptent acheter avec les paysannes et paysans  producteurs du village de Coni 800kg de maïs, 300kg de sorgho pour les revendre au comptant et en détail sur le marché de Coni aux revendeurs et consommateurs venant d’ailleurs.
Elles espèrent réaliser 17 500 FCFA de bénéfice  chacune avec ce prêt, qui servira à aider les époux à subvenir aux dépenses de la famille.
texts.en:
Mostly married women, the members of the Dembagnouma group have an average age of 26 and on average, 3 children. They live in traditional extended conjugal families with their husbands, sisters and brothers. They reside in the village of Coni, Sous-prefecture of Fana, region of Koulikoro, Republic of Mali.

They met through their businesses, since in fact they all sell cereals. With the intention of developing their businesses, these women joined the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are on their third solidarity loan (group loan). Both the preceding loans were correctly reimbursed.

The members of the group intend to buy, from the women and men of the village of Coni who farm the crops, 800 kg of maize and 300 kg of sorghum which they will re-sell, for cash, at the market of Coni and also to retailers and consumers who come from other places.

With this loan, they each expect to make 17,500 F CFA in profit , which will be used to help their husbands support their families.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of cereals for re-sale

loans.name: Angélica

texts.es:
Angélica ya lleva doce años con su negocio de pescado en el mercado de Huaycán. Con su esposo tiene un puestito, juntos trabajan e invierten en su negocio, y juntos cubren los gastos de su hogar. Los tres hijos que tienen ya son mayores de edad e independientes económicamente.
Anteriormente Angélica trabajaba en servicios de casa, además se ocupaba de la crianza de sus hijos cuando todavía eran menores. Sin embargo, a sus treinta y siete años y desde hace doce años, se animó a intentar formar un negocio propio, y le fue bien. 
Aunque en los últimos tres años, durante los cuales ha estado recibiendo los préstamos de EDAPROSPO, ha podido invertir más en su negocio. En un futuro le gustaría cambiar de comercio y en vez de un puesto de pescado en el mercado, tener una tienda de abarrotes.
texts.en:
Angélica has been selling fish in the Huaycán market for 12 years. She shares a post with her husband, and they work, invest and cover their expenses together. The three children they have are grown up and economically independent. Previously, Angélica worked as a housekeeper in addition to bringing up her children while they were still young. At the age of 37, however, and for the past 12 years, she has been driven to form her own business, and it has gone well. In the past three years, while receiving loans from Edaprospo, she has been able to invest even more in her business. In the future, she would like to switch from selling fish at the market to running a grocery store.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in capital for fish business and cover some personal costs

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary A. is married and has three children. She has received no formal education. Mary sells groceries like milk, Milo, canned products and other iems in Abura, which she has done since 1994. Her husband is a plumber. Mary uses her income to assist her husband with the housekeeping expenses.

Mary will use the loan as additional capital to enable her to increase stocks of groceries like milk, Milo, canned products and others to meet the increase in demand by her customers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Mary plans to reinvest back in the expansion of her trade.

loans.use: To increase stock of groceries like milk, Milo, canned products and other items

loans.name: Islom

texts.ru: Ислом 26 летний молодой человек, отец двоих детей. Занимается откормом и продажей скота. А также имеет бизнес по продаже плетёного камыша, которого используют для покрытия полов новых домов .Т.к. в районах  Учбог вместо деревянных полов оставляют землю и покрывают данным покрытием, и застеливают коврами. Это изделие имеет большой спрос у сельского населения. Ислом решил получить кредит для увеличения товарооборота скота.
texts.en:
Islom is a young man of 26 years of age, a father of two children. He is raising and selling cattle. He also has a business selling woven cane which is used to cover the floors of new homes. Because in the regions of Uchbog this type of covering is used instead of the wooden floors and then covered with rugs. This product has a high demand among the village population. Islom decided to get a loan to increase the commodity circulation of cattle.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a cattle

loans.name: Tumaini Group

texts.en:
Bertha has been animal keeper in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya. She currently earns very minimal monthly profit. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can increase the number of her animals and buy more food and medicine for them. She is hoping that, through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Bertha is 45 years old, widowed, and has seven children: ages 25, 22, 18, 17, 15, 12 and 10. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Quen, who has her own small business in Mbeya selling bananas.

loans.use: To increase the number of her animals and to buy more food and medicine for them

loans.name: Kalsoom Mai Allah Baksh Group

texts.en:
Kalsoom mai baji has resided in a city named Multan, Pakistan for the past 15 years. Her husband’s name is A. B. and he runs a business selling embroidered scarves. He has four years of experience in this business and collects orders from the clothes shops so as to earn income.

Kalsoom baji plays a very important part in his business. She prepares embroidered scarves for him so that he is able to complete the orders on time. They are both very hardworking people. She is applying for a loan to buy material (cloth, colored thread and beads) to complete the orders of her husband’s business.

She is the group leader of three other women from her locality:

Zarina baji wants a loan to buy material (flour, potatoes, spices and cooking oil) for her business selling Punjabi food.

Nasreen baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine for sewing clothes.

Naseem baji wants a loan to buy iron for making iron rods to sell.

loans.use: To buy material for preparing embroidered scarves

loans.name: Claudia Lisseth

texts.es: Claudia Lisseth L. D. E. vive en el municipio D. Apopa ubicado en el departamento D. San Salvador, Claudia vive con su esposo y dos hijas Alejandra D. 9 años D. edad y Andrea D. 6 años D. edad ambas estudian en la escuela. Claudia se dedica al comercio,  ella venD. productos como perfumes, cremas, desodorantes, etc. Claudia mantiene un inventario D. variedad D. productos en su casa, pero también trabaja por pedidos ya que también se ocupa D.  revista en la que las personas pueden ver los artículos y pedirlos. El método D. trabajo D. Claudia es visitar a sus clientes D. casa en casa con la revista y con un inventario D. la mercadería que ella dispone, ella solicita este crédito por que quiere comprar más productos para aumentar su inventario en existencia.
texts.en:
Claudia Lisseth L. D. E. lives in the Apopa municipality, which is located in the San Salvador department. Claudia lives with her husband and her two daughters; Alejandra is 9, and Andrea is 6. Both girls attend school. Claudia sells products like perfumes, creams, deodorants, etc. Claudia keeps an inventory of a variety of products in her house. But, she also works by taking orders. She also has a catalog where people can see items and order them. Claudia’s method of working is to visit her customers door to door with the catalog and some inventory of the available merchandise. She is asking for this loan because she wants to buy more products to increase her existing inventory.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy products to increase her inventory

location.town: Apopa en el departamento de San Salvador

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
Nida Z. is from the town of Capatan, Tuguegarao City. She is 42 years old. Nida is married to a farmer in their village and has 7 children. The eldest has already graduated college while the other six children are currently studying in college, high school and in elementary level. To make a living, Nida owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale and also rice farming. 

Nida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nida is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be taken out by Nida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business and she wants the children to finish their studies in order to have a better future.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the pioneer microfinance institutions in the Philippines committed to serve the needy in Central and Northern Luzon through socio-economic development and holistic transformation.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Yovana

texts.es:
La señora Yovana pertenece al Banco Comunal “Manuela de Hoy”  que esta ubicado en el distrito de Ilave, Provincia de El Collao, Departamento de Puno, ella tiene 24 años de edad, de estado civil casada y es madre de 01 hijo.  Tiene estudios de secundaria completa, vive en la Parcialidad de Camicachi.

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace 05 años,  su primer préstamo fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles el cual utilizó para la compra de cereales. 

En este momento ella requiere un préstamo de S/. 3000.00 Nuevos soles, para la compra de cereales como trigo, cebada, avena, etc.

Su deseo es comprar al por mayor y llevar a diferentes ferias de su zona.

A ella le gustan los ahorros y las charlas.
texts.en:
Yovana belongs to the village bank "Manuela de Hoy," which is located in the district of Ilave, Province of El Collao, Department of Puno. She is 24 years old, married under common law, and the mother of 1 child. She has graduated from high school and lives in the Parcialidad de Camicachi. She has worked with the Movimiento Manuela Ramos for 5 years. Her first loan of $100 was used to buy cereals. Now she needs a loan of $1,000 to buy cereals such as wheat, barley, oats, etc. She wishes to buy larger quantities and take them to various street markets in her area. She enjoys savings and conversations.

Translated from Spanish by Jeff Schell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of wheat, barley, oats, etc.

loans.name: Betty's Group

texts.en: Betty N. is the leader of the Nyikira Okole group in Kikajjo. She is a very hardworking 30-year-old mother of 2 children, aged 4 and 7, who also cares for 2 orphans belonging to her late sister. Betty has owned and operated the Seaman Bar for 3 years, and so far her business is good. It’s from the profits derived from the bar that she is able to pay school fees for her dependents plus their general care. She hopes to expand the bar with more space, and more beers and sodas, once she has access to the loan, since she hopes to buy a plot of land with the proceeds. She still has her hopes of one day owning a beer and soda depot to be able to supply other retailers.

loans.use: To buy more beers and sodas and wines for the bar

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
At the age of 71, Norma is not yet retiring from her role being a mother to her three children and a wife to her husband. In fact, the role she plays is now broad for she is also a backbone for her grandchildren wherein she helps her children send their children to school. This is the reason why Norma has to make the rest of her lives productive by growing a business to be inherited by her children and grandchildren in the future. 

For the fulfillment of her dream, Norma thought of having a business capital to start with. She joined Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI) in 2008 and made a loan. She bought piglets for her hog fattening (pig raising) business then. Profit she had with this kind of business is every after four months. Piglets she bought amounting to Php1,700-Php2,500 when sold after four months will cost Php6,000 each. 

After several loans Norma made in ASHI, she has able to finance her husband and son's business which is planting of rice. With her family supporting her and her businesses, Norma has able to keep her good performance in terms of payment, attendance in center meetings of and business. These have made her qualified to make bigger amount of loans to ASHI. Norma takes the opportunity making bigger amount of loan because she wanted her businesses to grow and for her children to have their own source of income through her.

loans.use: Finance her farming business and to be used in buying necessary farm inputs.

loans.name: Maria Norma

texts.es:
La señora Maria Norma V. es socia del Banco Comunal “La Unión de La Mujer,” un grupo grande de señoras que se reúnen cada 15 días en un centro educativo ubicado en el barrio de Santa Mónica, en la ciudad de Manta, en la costa ecuatoriana. Es un banquito antiguo que ya lleva 37 ciclos de crédito con la institución. 

La Sra. Maria Norma Vélez es socia fundadora del grupo, entonces ya lleva muchos años sacando créditos de la fundación. Dice que le gusta mucho trabajar con el grupo. Ella tiene 62 años, es casada y tiene 5 hijos, los cuales ya son mayores con familias propias. Ya tiene 14 nietos!

Maria Norma vive en el mismo barrio Santa Mónica, donde ella creció, y 3 de sus hermanos siguen viviendo en el barrio junto con ella (pero en sus propias casas). La señora se dedica a la venta de ropa a crédito, trabaja de forma ambulante, va de casa en casa para vender. Lleva más que 20 años con este negocio. Ahora sus ventas están un poco bajas por la situación de la economía global, pero dice que por lo general le va bastante bien con este negocio.

Nos cuenta que a veces tiene que salir a buscar sus clientes para que le paguen, pero no tiene muchas problemas porque la mayoría de su clientela es de confianza. También tiene otro negocio de venta de cervezas y bebidas gaseosas en su casa. 

Actualmente está pidiendo un crédito para poder comprar ropa y cerveza. Dice que su meta para el futuro es seguir con sus negocios y con su banco comunal.
texts.en:
Señora Maria Norma V. is a member of the communal bank, "La Unión de La Musjer," a large group of women that meets every two weeks in an educational center located in the neighborood of Santa Mónica, in the city of Manta, on the Ecuadorian coast. It is an established bank that has had 37 loans with the institution. Señora Maria Norma V. is the founding member of the group, so she has many years of experience taking out loans from the institution. She says that she likes to work with the group. She is 62, is married, and has 5 children, who are adults with their own families. She already has 14 grandchildren! Maria Norma lives in the same neighborhood of Santa Mónica, where she grew up. Three of her siblings also continue living in this neighborhood with her (but in their own houses). She sells clothing on credit. She works by traveling from house to house to make sales. She has had this business for more than 20 years. Her sales are a little low now because of the global economic situation, but she says that in general her business is going rather well for her. She tells us that at times she has to go out collect money from her customers, but she doesn't have many problems because the majority of her clientele is trustworthy. She also has another business of selling beer and beverages in her home. Currently she is asking for a credit to buy clothing and beer. She says that her goal for the future is to continue with her businesses and her communal bank

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise to supply her businesses (clothing and beverages)

loans.name: Lucy Margarita

texts.en: Lucy is a member of the Sun and Moon Village Bank.  She is 55 years old and married with six children over age 18.  Lucy is a seamstress. She began working when she was 17 years old.  After she studied sewing she began working from her house. The last few years, her business has dropped because people do not want sewn things anymore. Since 2002, Lucy has run a taxi service with her husband.  They have two cars that her husband and son use as taxis.  Lucy has been with FINCA for 7 years. With the loans, she has been able to purchase their two cars. Lucy needs a loan of 1000 soles, which she is going to use to repair the two cars. Her dream is to buy another car so that another of her sons can work in the family business as well.

loans.use: To repair the two taxis.

loans.name: Aurora

texts.es:
Aurora es socia del Banco Comunal Tulipanes.
Aurora es conviviente, tiene 31 años y 2 hijos, Aurora tiene un salón de belleza llamado Aurora, actividad que realiza eventualmente. Además Aurora junto a su esposo tienen un carro con el cual realizan transporte publico.
Aurora necesita un préstamo de 600 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de neumáticos.
Los sueños de Aurora son mejorar su negocio y comprar otro carro mas moderno.
texts.en:
Aurora is a member of "Banco Comunal Tulipanes. She lives with her significant other, she is 31 years old and has 2 children. Aurora has a beauty parlor named Aurora where she works eventually. Besides, together with her husband they own a car used for public transportation.

Aurora needs a loan of 600 soles to be invested in buying tires. It is her dream to improve business and purchase a more modern car.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase tires for a vehicle.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is 32 years old and married to Edgar, a businessman. They have two children: Jay Mar, who is 12 years old and in grade 6, and Jarred Dane, who is 6 years old and in grade 1. They live in the city proper of Cauayan, Isabela. 

Agnes manages a mini-restaurant next to Cauayan Medical Specialist Hospital. Her net income a week is 1,800 PHP.  She wishes to expand her business for it to become more profitable. This is the reason why she is borrowing a loan of 30,000 PHP from the Kiva lenders for her to pursue her plans in her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her food vending business

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel G. is 21 years old and married to a community leader. She has two children who both go to school. G. is currently in the business of selling fish, onions and tomatoes, and is requesting a loan to buy more items, such as beans and rice, for resale. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a large retail shop.

About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted at returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase other food items to sell

loans.name: Kadidia

texts.fr:
Madame Kadidia B. a 30 ans, mariée et  mère de deux enfant elle vit avec son époux et leurs enfants à Sanoubougou I- Kapel Kourou, un des  quartiers périphériques de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali)
Kadidia après avoir mené beaucoup d’activité sans succès, s’est initiée à l’activité d’achat et de  vente d’huiles alimentaires, de couscous arabe et  de cube maggie  il y a environ sept ans. 
Elle mène son activité à la maison et au marché de son quartier où elle dispose  d’une place. Elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a environ deux ans. Elle est actuellement à son 2ème prêt individuel et le précédent a été bien remboursé.
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 6 bidons d’huiles alimentaires, 2 cartons de couscous arabe et 4 cartons de cubes maggies. 
Elle  achète ses marchandises sur commande à Bobo Dioulasso (au Burkina Faso) et aussi dans les huileries de place avant de les revendre en détail, au comptant et à crédit au marché de son quartier ,à une clientèle composée des femmes. .
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Ms. Kadidia B., aged 30, is married and the mother of two children.  She lives with her husband and their children in Sanoubougou I- Kapel Kourou, an outlying district of the city of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  After having run many businesses unsuccessfully, she got introduced to the business of buying and selling cooking oils, Arabian couscous, and Maggie bouillon cubes about seven years ago.  She operates at her house and at the market in her district, where she has a spot.  She is in high demand by her customers for the quality of her goods.  To satisfy her burgeoning customer base, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso about two years ago.  She is now on her second individual loan.  The preceding one has been repaid.  With this loan, she intends to buy 6 containers of cooking oil, 2 boxes of Arabian couscous, and 4 boxes of Maggie cubes.   Supplies of these goods are gotten by special order from Dioulasso (in Burkina Faso) and also from local oil producers.  She then sells at the retail level, cash or credit accepted, to customers composed of women at the district marketplace. With this loan, she envisions realizing a monthly profit of 100,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to augment her working capital, to help cover family expenses, and to pay the loan interest.  The rest will be invested into the business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Grocery items to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients for her genge business.

loans.name: Florinda

texts.es:
Florinda tiene 59 años, vive en su casa propia con su hijo Jhon, con quien también trabaja.
Desde hace 10 años se dedica a la venta de figuras de yeso; tales como alcancías, adornos, utensilio para la cocina, etc. Esta labor es la principal fuente de sustento para su hogar, ya que se dedica exclusivamente a ello. Florinda compra al por mayor todos estos adornos para posteriormente venderlos en los diferentes mercados de la ciudad, pero no de forma ambulatoria o individualmente, sino que ella recibe pedidos de los comerciantes y los abastecen
Para el futuro, Florinda espera tener una tienda donde pueda vender estos adornos al por mayor.

Este es su quinto crédito con MFP, siendo una persona muy puntual y responsable en todos sus pagos.  Con el dinero que solicita comprará mayor cantidad de mercadería para aumentar sus ventas en la temporada navideña.
texts.en:
Florinda is 59 years old, and lives in her own house with her son Jhon, who also works. For ten years she has worked selling plaster items, such as piggy-banks, decorations, kitchenware, etc. This activity is her principle source of household income, and the only job she works at. Florinda buys all of her items wholesale to then sell them at various markets around the city. She doesn't do this travelling around on foot, selling individual pieces, but instead takes orders from businesspeople and then fills those orders. For the future, Florinda hopes to have a store where she can sell her items wholesale. This is her fifth loan with MFP, as she is a very punctual person and responsible with her payments. With the money she is asking for, she will buy more merchandise to increase her Christmas sales.

Translated from Spanish by Shaun Haines, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing merchandise for sale for the Christmas season

loans.name: Prima

texts.en:
Prima G. is from the village of Cabisera 27. She is 38 years-old and married with two school-aged children. Prima owns and operates a business in the agriculture sector raising pigs for sale. Prima has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Prima joined Kiva partner ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Prima has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. Prima is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Prima from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support extended members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and North-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed.

loans.name: Las Praderas Group

texts.es:
El grupo Praderas lo conforman Tania Auxiliadora A. Z., Eugenia del Carmen Gaitán C. y Elizabeth del Socorro C. tres féminas trabajadoras las cuales desean seguir trabajando y que su negocio crezca.
 
La joven A. Z. de 22 años con ayuda de sus padres cumplió su sueño pera tener su propio taller de calzado. En el trabajan arduamente ella y su hermano en la realización y comercialización del producto.

Eugenia del Carmen Gaitán C.  tiene una mini pulpería la cual desea tener más grande y surtida. Mientras Elizabeth del Socorro C. quien vende leña desea tener un tramo en el mercado.
texts.en:
The Praderas group is made up of Tania Auxiliadora A. Z., Eugenia del Carmen Gaitán C., and Elizabeth del Socorro C. three hard-working women who hope to continue working and growing their businesses. A. Z., 22 years old, achieved her dream of opening a shoe shop with her parents help. She and her brother work arduously in the shop making and selling their shoes. Eugenia del Carmen Gaitán C. has a small market which she wants to be bigger and better supplied. Meanwhile, Elizabeth del Socorro C. sells firewood and wants to have a lot in the market.

Translated from Spanish by Patrick King, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For leather, soles, glue, nails, etc.

loans.name: Ileana Matilde

texts.es: La joven Ileana tiene la edad de 28 años, lo cual ha logrado ser una joven emprendedora, casada y con dos hijos, su esposo trabaja como jefe del departamento en la supervisión en el supermercado la Unión, pues gracia a el que le ha dado dinero de su salario y con su esfuerzo. Logro poner una pulpería que la hecho crecer en inventario pues vende una variedad de productos, lo cual ha logrado con los financiamiento de Afodenic el cual se ha beneficiado para mejorar en su negocio como su vida personal. Con este préstamo invertirá en granos básicos como: arroz, frijoles, azúcar, aceite, maíz, jabón, papel higiénico, golosinas, gaseosas, jugos, cereales, lácteos, pollo y carne, como también invertir una parte en ropa para niñas, niños y adultos, cosméticos el cual se vende mucho y queda buena ganancias. Lo que mas desea es poder tener su casa propia ya que vive junto con su mama, lo cual desea tener mejor privacidad y una casa para sus hijos que espera lograr este anhelo como madres.
texts.en:
Ileana, age 28, has become an enterprising young woman. She is married and has two children. Her husband works as head of the department of supervision in the Unión supermarket. She was able to set up a min-market thanks to her husband, who gave her money from his salary, and her effort. She has increased her inventory; she sells a variety of products. She did this with the loan from Afodenic. This has been helpful in improving her business and her personal life. She will use this loan to buy basic items like rice, beans, sugar, oil, corn, soap, toilet paper, sweets, soft drinks, juice, grains, dairy products, chicken, and meat. She will use part to buy clothing for children and adults. She will also buy cosmetics, which she sells a lot and gets good earnings. What she wants most is to be able to have her own house. She now lives with her mother, and she wants to have more privacy. As a mother she also longs to have a house for her children.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy  rice, beans, sugar, oil, corn, soap, toilet paper, sweets, soft drinks, juice, grains, dairy products, chicken, and meat.  She will also buy clothing and cosmetics.

loans.name: Abdulai's Group

texts.en:
These are teachers at a secondary school in Tombo village, near Freetown, Sierra Leone’s capital city. This school was established in 1993 and it currently has 20 teachers on its payroll. Eight out of the 20 have applied for a loan of SLL 8,200,000 from SMT (a partner of Shine on Sierra Leone in Waterloo)/Kiva lenders in order to meet their immediate financial challenges. 

School staff from this institution, like many other schools' staff within SMT’s operational areas, come to SMT to apply for loans. With the help of these loans, they can accomplish certain tasks that they would otherwise have not been able to accomplish with their mere salaries alone. But with the help of this loan, some can pay school fees for their children; others can use the loan to buy pieces of furniture, a plot of land, house-building materials, or invest in business. At the end of each month, these teachers can repay the loan out of their monthly salaries. The institution’s bursar is directly responsible for deducting the repayment and pays SMT on their behalf.

Forty-three-year-old Abdulai J. (first row, first from left) is the Acting Vice Principal at the school.  He was born in Tombo village, is married to a businesswoman, and they have 4 children. Mr. J. has been a teacher for 14 years now. With his share of this loan, he will buy house-building materials – cement, bundles of corrugated zinc, etc. 

(Attached to the photo are other group members who were not present for the group snapshot.)

loans.use: Buy house-building materials

loans.name: Maria Isabel

texts.es:
La señora MARIA ISABEL V. G. tiene 40 años, vive en la provincia de Trujillo, departamento La Libertad – Perú. Pertenece al Banco Comunal LA PERBOLA II. La socia  presenta estudios hasta 4to de Secundaria, es casada, tiene 4 hijos de los cuales 2 dependen económicamente de ella. María se dedica a confección y venta de sandalias, zapatos y zapatillas para damas y caballero. Para la fabricación de este calzado ella utiliza cuero, cuerina, hilos, plantillas, pegamento, etc. Estos productos los compra al por mayor en una tienda distribuidora del distrito del porvenir porque es allí donde puede comprar a menor costo  y así poder generar mayores ganancias.
Con su primer crédito de 300.00 nuevos soles compró 2 docenas de zapatos.
Con este nuevo crédito de 300.00 nuevos soles fabricará calzado escolar para niñas y niños, en diferentes tallas y modelos. Ella sueña con aumentar sus ventas para así poder generar dinero para su hogar y los gastos de sus hijos.
texts.en:
María Isabel Visitación García is 40, and she lives in the Trujillo province, La Libertad department, Perú. She belongs to the La Perbola II Communal Bank. She attended school until the fourth year of high school. She is married and has four children. Two of the children are economically dependent upon her. María makes and sells sandals, shoes, and slippers for women and men. To make this footwear she uses leather, synthetic leather, thread, insoles, and glue, etc. She buys these products wholesale in the Porvenir district from a store that distributes goods. That is where she is able to buy at less cost. Therefore, she is able to able to generate greater earnings. With her first loan for 300 PEN she bought two dozen shoes. With this new loan for 300 PEN, she will make different sizes and styles of school shoes for girls and boys. She dreams of increasing her sales in order to generate money for her household and her children’s expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy school shoes for girls and boys

loans.name: Stephen Kimani

texts.en:
Stephen Kimani, 62, is married to Tabitha Kimani and they are blessed with four beautiful children. He lives in Msalaba in Eldoret and he practices farming which he has done for the last thirty-five years. Besides farming Stephen also operates a ploughing business at his place in Msalaba near the Ivugwi primary school.

Stephen was introduced to KADET by another client. Stephen plans to use this loan for farm inputs, like maize seedlings, and for payroll for his farm's employees. 

His dream is to be economically stable and thus also provide the basic needs for his family, including food, clothing, and shelter.

loans.use: Farm inputs and payroll

loans.name: Teresa Del Carmen

texts.es:
la sra. Teresa del Carmen C. tiene 63 años de edad, vive en El Banquito, El Corpus Choluteca. Teresa se dedica a la venta de productos de consumo popular, tiene una pulperia que esta ubicada en su casa de habitacion.
Teresa es una persona de edad y esta es su unica fuente de ingresos, el prestamo lo utilizara para comprar mas mercaderia para su negocio y asi poder surtirla ya que las exigencias de sus clientes son bastantes.
las ganancias las ocupara para cubrir con los gastos del hogar.
nos comento que se siente muy feliz ya que su negocio es estable.
texts.en:
Teresa del Carmen C. is 63 years old and lives in El Banquito, El Corpus Choluteca. She works selling popular consumables, and has a grocery store located in he house. Teresa is an older person and this is her only source of income. The loan will be used to purchase more merchandise for her business to stock it as the demands of her customers are quite high. The earnings she gets cover the household costs. Teresa tells us that she feels very happy now that her business is stable.

Translated from Spanish by Jane McCrory, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase batteries, juice, soaps, oil, butter and other grocery items

loans.name: Odo Pa Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Catherine calls herself a hard-working and honest wife of an ex-service man. She has 6 children but only 3 are currently dependent on her for their schooling and livelihood. She operates her business in a rented stall and retails maize, rice, yams and groundnuts. She has been in this business for the past 14 years and has supported the family with the income from the business ever since her husband retired. Catherine hopes to own her own store in Pokukrom, a suburb of Kumasi where she lives with her family.

Catherine is the leader of 'Odo Pa Trust' bank comprised of 5 members. Odo Pa simply means sincere love and members of the group are into the sale of vegetables, palm oil, plantains and cassava. Catherine was selected as the leader because of her hard work and her sense of responsibility. The group intend to use the loan to expand their businesses.

loans.use: To purchase bags of maize and rice

loans.name: Tha's Group

texts.en: Five people residing in Spean Daek village in Kandal Province comprise this group loan, led by Mrs. Tha K., and will use the loan for a variety of purposes. Although Tha, a lotus seller at her local market and her husband, Mr. Khloeng Chorn, a fisherman, try to work hard, their income is often insufficient to support their family living.  Therefore, to improve their living conditions, Tha is requesting a loan to fix her house. She is a mother of three children, one of whom is a laborer, while the others are attending local public school.

loans.use: To fix her house

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina S. lives in the village of Natugod in Misamis Oriental. She is 54 years old, married and has two grown children. She makes a living by running a sari-sari (or variety) store where she sells food and other products used daily by people in her community. She has been engaged in this line of work for more than three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Josefina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid two previous loans from HSPFI and is applying for a new one, for 11,000 PHP, to expand her business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by her store to support her family. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to expand her small business

loans.name: Nadezhda

texts.en:
Nadezhda is married with two grown children. She lives in Novaya Kahovka. Nadezhda sells retail merchandise in one the local marketplaces in her home town. Her inventory includes socks, pantyhose, pareos, swimsuits and speedos. She has been in this business for 16 years. Currently, her turnover capital amounts to 15,000 Grivnyas. Net profit is 6,000 Grivnyas a month. Nadezhda has 24,000 Grivnyas worth of inventory. 

Nadezhda is seeking a loan of 13,000 Grivnyas to purchase a variety of summer merchandise for this vending season. She is an experienced entrepreneur who knows the demand and uses her knowledge to attract more customers. Nadezhda says her business is the main source of income for her family which is why she works hard to keep it running efficiently and bringing in a stable income.

loans.use: to purchase summer merchandise

loans.name: Mujeres Dinamicas ["dynamic Women"] Group

texts.es:
La alcancía comunal “Mujeres Dinámicas” está conformado por 9 socios emprendedores, quienes viven en la zona D. Virgen del Carmen, distrito D. Ate, departamento D. Lima, trabajan con EDAPROSPO – prosperidad desD. hace un 13 años.
Juana asume el cargo D. presidenta desD. hace 6 años, tiene 36 años, es casada, tiene 2 hijos D. 8 y 14 años D. edad. Se dedica a la venta D. golosinas, galletas, chocolates y gaseosas, desD. hace 3 años, con el esfuerzo D. su labor diaria Juana cubre los gastos D. servicios, alimentación y el pago D. la academia D. su hija, su gran sueño es tener un taller D. confecciones en su hogar, el reciente préstamo obtenido lo utilizará en la compra D. mercadería, para así poder satisfacer la demanda D. clientes.
Los socios tienen grandes sueños y metas y se encuentran, muy agradecidos con la institución por todo el apoyo brindado y se comprometen a cumplir con los pagos, seguir trabajando y no defraudarlos. (Niño en la foto hijo D. la socia).
Socia en la foto pequeña no pudo asistir al desembolso por motivos D. trabajo, llego mas tarD..
texts.en:
The “Mujeres Dinámicas” ["Dynamic Women"] communal bank is maD. up of 9 enterprising members, who live in the area called Virgen del Carmen, in Ate district, Department of Lima. They have been working with EDAPROSPO Prosperity for about 13 years. Juana took over the position of president of the group 6 years ago. She is married and has 2 children, aged 8 and 14. For the past three years, she has worked selling snacks, cookies, chocolates and soft drinks. With the effort of her daily work, Juana is able to pay for the family's food and services, as well as the school fees for her daughter. Her great dream is to have a tailor's workshop in her home. She used the funds from this loan to buy merchandise so she can satisfy her customers' requests. The members of this group have great dreams and goals, and they are very grateful to the institution for all of the support provided to them. They are committed to making their payments, continuing to work and not defrauding anyone. The boy in the photo is Juana's son. The member in the small photo was not able to attend the loan distribution because she was working, so she arrived later.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying merchandise to satisfy her customers

loans.name: La Esperanza Del Valle Group

texts.es:
LA SRA. GARDENIA TIENE 34 AÑOS TIENE UNA HIJA D. 14 AÑOS, QUIEN ES SU INSPIRACIÓN Y ALICIENTE PARA ESFORZARSE Y TRABAJAR CADA DÍA PARA SACARLA ADELANTE Y DARLE LO NECESARIO PARA LLEGAR A SER UNA PROFESIONAL MAS ADELANTE. LA SRA. GARDENIA EN INTEGRANTE DEL GRUPO "LA ESPERANZA DEL VALLE" FORMADO POR 10 PERSONAS QUIENES VIVEN EN LA URBANIZACIÓN LUCIANA EN EL DISTRITO D. CARABAYLLO. SUS COMPAÑEROS LA ELIGIERON COMO TESORERA D. LA JUNTA DIRECTIVA DEL GRUPO.
HACE TRES AÑOS LA SRA. GARDENIA SE DEDICA A LA VENTA D. ROPA Y PRODUCTOS D. BELLEZA OFRECIENDO A SUS FAMILIARES Y AMIGOS; EMPEZÓ VENDIENDO PRODUCTOS D. BELLEZA POR CATALOGO, LUEGO SUS MISMOS CLIENTES LE EMPEZARONA HACER PEDIDOS D. ROPA, POR LO QUE SE ANIMÓ A HACERSE D. UN STOCK.
CON ÉSTE NEGOCIO HA PODIDO TENER UN CAPITAL D. TRABAJO, TENER UN STOCK TANTO EN PRODUCTOS D. BELLEZA COMO EN LA LINEA D. ROPA.
LE GUSTARÍA MAS ADELANTE PONER UN NEGOCIO D. CABINAS D. INTERNET.
EL PRESTAMO SOLICITADO LO INVERTIRÁ EN LA COMPRAV D. ROPA D. INVIERNO PARA NIÑOS, JOVENES Y ADULTOS, PARA LO CUAL YA TIENE PEDIDOS.
texts.en:
Sra. Gardenia is 34 years old and has a 14 year old daughter who is her inspiration and incentive to strive and work each day to move forward and proviD. everything necessary so that she can become a professional. She is a member of the group “La Esperanza del Valle” (The Hope of the Valley), which consists of ten individuals who live in the development of Luciana in the district of Carabayllo. Her fellow members elected her to be the treasurer of the group’s Board of Directors.

Sra. Gardenia has been selling clothing and beauty products for three years, offering her goods to relatives and friends. She began selling beauty products through catalogs, but later her customers started placing orders for clothing. This encouraged her to build up an inventory of merchandise. With this business, she will be able to have operating capital to maintain a stock of beauty products as well as clothing. Sometime later on she would like to start another business providing Internet services.

The loan she is requesting will be invested in the purchase of winter clothing for children, teenagers, and adults since she has already received orders.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase winter clothing for children, teenagers, and adults

loans.name: Yaya

texts.fr:
Monsieur Yaya D.  est âgé de 40 ans, marié et père de deux enfants. Il réside avec sa famille dans sa propre maison à Banconi, un des quartiers périphériques de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
 Après une formation de thérapeute, il s’est vite initié aux activités pharmaceutiques depuis plus de vingt ans. Avec une telle longue expérience dans ce domaine, il jouit d’une forte réputation et accueille beaucoup de commandes, mais les ressources nécessaires pour satisfaire ces besoins font défaut. 
Ainsi, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il a déjà bénéficié 2 prêts individuels, tous correctement remboursés. 
Dans le cadre de toujours mieux améliorer son activité, il sollicite un  troisième prêt qui lui permettra d’acheter 10 cartons de Manames, 9 bidons d’inzam indien, 3 cartons d’Aloé. 
Il s’approvisionnera à Lomé (république de Togo); auparavant (avant son adhésion à Soro Yiriwaso) il s’approvisionnait auprès de son fournisseur à Koutiala pour venir les revendre à Sikasso dans sa pharmacopée située à la gare routière de Sikasso à une clientèle composée des voyageurs et surtout de routiers. Certains de ses clients payent au comptant, d’autre à crédit. 
Avec ce prêt, il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 300 000 FCFA. Avec ces bénéfices réalisés, il compte résoudre l’essentielle de ses dépenses, celles de sa famille, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Yaya D. is 40 years old, married and father to two children. He lives with his family in his own house in Banconi, one of the outer suburbs of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Having trained as a therapist, he launched himself rapidly into the pharmaceutical business more than twenty years ago. With such a long experience in this domain, he enjoys a good reputation and gets a lot of orders; his resources are however insufficient to satisfy these needs. He thus decided to join the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, from which he has already had two individual loans, both of which were repaid correctly. With a view to constantly improving his business, he is requesting a third loan which will allow him to buy ten cartons of "manames", nine containers of Indian "inzam" and three cartons of Aloe (natural medecines). He gets his supplies in Lomé (in the Republic of Togo); previously (before he joined Soro Yiriwaso) he stocked up from his supplier in Koutiala in order to resell in his pharmacy in Sikasso's bus station to a customer base made up of travelers, and above all lorry drivers. Some of his customers pay cash and others buy on credit. With this loan, he expects to make a monthly profit of 300,000FCFA. With the profits he makes he hopes to be able to cover the bulk of his expenses and those of his family, as well as paying the interest on his loan; the rest will be invested in his business.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of medicines

loans.name: Fidele

texts.fr: N. Fidèle est homme né en 1982 à Kamonyi, ancien préfecture de Gitarama, il vit actuellement en province de Kigali, capital du Rwanda. Il est jeune marié, Il fait le commerce de viande à Nyabugogo  en secteur de Muhima. Avec le prêt il veut acheter une vache pour viande de son boucherie, la clientèle des viandes est permanant car il les fournit des restaurent qui lui payent mensuellement. Les mouvements des clients   lui permettent de vider très rapidement le stock et avoir la nécessité d’acheter beaucoup des vaches à abattre et vendre beaucoup des viandes. Les épargnes continuelles lui permet de la survie de sa famille en payant le loyer, dans l’avenir il veut avoir sa propre maison car il loue, et planifier pour le bon futur de  sa famille.
texts.en:
Fidèle N. was born in 1982 in Kamonyi, in the former prefecture of Gitarama, and he currently lives in the province of Kigali, the capital of Rwanda. A young married man, he trades in meat at Nyabugogo in the sector of Muhima. With this loan, he wants to buy a cow to supply meat for his butcher's shop. He has regular meat customers because he supplies restaurants and he is paid monthly. Because of his customers' transactions, he quickly depletes his stock and needs to buy more cows to slaughter and to sell much more meat. He has been able to meet the needs of his family and pay the rent by continually saving. In the future, he would like to buy his own house as he currently rents, and he would like to plan for his family's future.

Translated from French by Sarah Puchner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a cow to slaughter and have meat

loans.name: Tilieta

texts.en:
Tilieta A. is 32, married, and has five children. She owns a business venture running bingo games. Tilieta has one year of experience in this business. She is requesting a loan of 1,000 WST to purchase game prizes. She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 350 WST per week) to improve and expand her business.
Tilieta joined Kiva partner, SPBD, in 2010, and this is her first loan. SPBD's loans are Tilieta's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase game prizes

loans.name: Chum

texts.en:
Chum S., 29, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. S. is a garment-factory worker, earning an income of $2 per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of $4 per day.

S. is requesting a loan of $600 to purchase a motorbike for the family to use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. S.'s husband appears in the photograph because S. is not available.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for the family to use

loans.name: Neba Florence

texts.en:
Neba Florence Manka’a was born in 1969. She married but is separated from her husband due to some difficulties. They are blessed with  five children and live in  Ntamulung, a district in Bamenda, North West Region of Cameroon.

Florence has faced some challenges in life.  She has been struggling with ill  health and the problem of poor  yield due to natural disasters. The most difficult problem has been raising capital for her business and  paying for her children’s education and building a house of her own.  She plans to invest this loan in agricultural products, namely in the production  of cash crops and other farm produce such as, cassava, corn, and cocoyams. 

She is most  especially interested in cassava which is used in the production of gari and water-fufu (staple dishes). She also plans to invest part in her general provisions store which will raise daily income for her family. She believes the business will succeed because she has been in the business for a long time and that she born a farmer and now she has become an expert in farming over the past years. She also thinks her approach to her customers will be captivating and hence lead to the success of her business. The loan will help her community because they will be able to afford at least three meals per day at reasonable prices.

Florence will plough back her profit into her business and use part to care for her family. She also will use the proceeds to pay her house rent and save for a rainy day. She prefers GHAPE because of the training she frequently receives and the low cost of obtaining and ease of paying back a loan.

About GHAPE 

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community in its clients and staff.

loans.use: Purchase of farm tools, fertilizer, and seedlings

loans.name: Pablo Roberto

texts.es:
Pablo, tiene 33 años de edad, vive con su esposa en Ozatlan departamento de Usulután, posee una panadería desde hace 4 años y trabajan juntos desde las 12 pm a 1 am, este negocio lo aprendió tomando un curso de panadería, él solicita un préstamo pues quiere fortalecer la panadería comprando sacos de harina suave y fuerte, harina de arroz, jalea, levadura, azúcar y leche.
Este préstamo le ayudara a ampliar su producción, mejorar la calidad del pan y abastecer la demanda, ofreciendo a los clientes diferentes clases de pan y con sabor distinto; Su aspiración de empresario es realizar cada día un excelente trabajo que le forme un mejor futuro junto a su esposa.
texts.en: Pablo is 33 years old and he lives with his wife in Ozatlan, in the community of Usulutan. He has had a bakery for the past 4 years, working along side his wife from 12pm until 1am. He learned the business from a bakery course. He requests a loan to supplement his bakery with the purchase of sacks of flour, rice flour, preserves, yeast, sugar and milk. This loan will help him increase production and improve the quality of the bread he makes. He will be able to fill client demand and he will be able to offer his clients various types of breads in different flavors. His goal as a small business owner is to do an excellent job every day, to forge a better future for himself and his wife.

loans.use: To purchase flour, preserves, and sugar.

loans.name: Mercy Efua Adgeiwa

texts.en: Mercy Efua Adgeiwa E. is married and has three children. She has attained junior high level of education. She sells costume jewelry at Abura. Mercy assists her husband in the upkeep of the home. The loan will enable her to purchase more jewelry and other items which are very often requested by her customers. Mercy plans to reinvest her additional revenue back into her business.

loans.use: purchase more costume jewelry and other items

loans.name: Gumercinda Josefina

texts.es: Gumercinda Josefina M. tiene 63 años de edad  con un gran entusiasmo por la venta de ropa con un estilo Polaco. Desea adquirir el crédito para invertir en la compra de prendas como ropa para dama y para niños, con la aspiración de que progrese su negocio. El préstamo que solicita es de ₡200.000 (Doscientos mil colones). Ella es socia de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal Credi Fácil R. G S.A, una de las 100 empresas asociadas por EDESA.
texts.en: Gumercinda Josefina M. is 63 years old with a lot of enthusiasm for the sale of clothing in the Polish style.  She wants to get this loan to invest in the purchase of items of clothing like women's  and children's clothes, with the aspiration of growing her business.  The loan that she is asking for is ₡200.000 (two hundred thousand colones).  She is a member of Empresa de Crédito Comunal Credi Fácil R. G S.A, one of the 100 businesses associated with EDESA.

loans.use: To purchase clothing to sell

loans.name: Renson

texts.en:
Renson is engaged in mixed farming in the town of Kitale in western Kenya and has farming in this way for 30 years. He produces milk, maize, beans, and eggs, which he sells at the local market. He is married with nine children, all of whom are adults save for the youngest who is still in school.

He has requested for this loan of 61,200 KES from Juhudi Kilimo in order to purchase and insure a dairy cow as well as to expand his poultry farm. He says his increased milk production will ensure that the family lives more comfortably. He hopes to acquire more dairy cows in order to gain greater income in future.

Renson mentions fluctuating market prices, costly animal feed, and diseases as his major business challenges. He adds that Juhudi Kilimo has empowered people who are now able to save their income.

loans.use: The purchase and insurance of a dairy cow and the expansion of his poultry farm

loans.name: Mansueta

texts.en:
Mansueta P. is from the village of Talahiron, Kibawe, Bukidnon. She is 50 years old. Mansueta is widowed and has 5 children. To make a living, Mansueta owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling seafood products  including fish such as sardines & mackerel in the local community. Mansueta has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Mansueta joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mansueta is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish such as sardines & milk fish. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Mansueta from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish such as sardines & milk fish

loans.name: Horonya Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe Horonya sont mariées majoritairement  dans des ménages monogames. Elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 33 ans, 3 enfants et habitent ensemble dans le village de Cinzana Gare, chef lieu d’une commune rurale dans la région de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali). Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté. 
Les membres du groupe font le commerce de parures, de laits, d’ustensiles plastiques et de pochettes. 
Dans le besoin d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer Soro Yiriwaso avec qui, elles sont à leur 4ème cycle de prêt.
 Madame Tata   Saré  est beaucoup sollicitée à Cinzana Gare pour sa vente d’ustensiles en plastiques de toutes sortes (pots, bols, assiettes, bassines, etc) surtout pendant les périodes de mariage. 
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 20 douzaines d’ustensiles en plastique composées de: pots, bols et assiettes. Elle se ravitaille au grand marché de Ségou et effectue sa vente au comptant et à crédit, à domicile, au marché de Cinzana Gare et dans les villages environnants à une clientèle composée de femmes et parfois d’hommes. 
Madame Tata   Saré espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 40 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et prendre en charge les besoins de condiments du foyer. 
Elle a pour objectif de s’investir dans l’élevage des petits ruminants dans le futur.
texts.en:
The four members of Horonya Group are married women. Most of them live in monogamous households. On average, they are 33 years old and have three children. They all live in the village of Cinzana Gare, the county town of a rural municipality in the region of Ségou (fourth administrative region of Mali). They know each other through ties of neighborhood and kinship.

The group members trade with fancy jewels, milk, plastic utensils and small handbags. Faced with the need to increase their working capital, the group members decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. This is their fourth cycle of solidarity loans.

Mrs Tata Saré sells all kinds of plastic utensils (pots, bowls, plates, basins, etc.) which are in high demand in Cinzana Gare, especially during wedding periods. She intends to use her loan to buy 20 dozens of sets of plastic utensils: pots, bowls and plates. She gets her supplies at the great market in Ségou and retails them from her home, at the market in Cinzana Gare and in the neighboring villages, for cash and credit, to a clientele made up women and sometimes men.

Mrs Tata Saré expects, thanks to this loan, to make an average profit of 40,000 CFA francs a month, which she will use to reinvest in her business and provide her family with food. Her goal for the future is to invest in rearing small ruminants.

loans.use: To buy plastic utensils

loans.name: Fausto Xavier

texts.es:
Fausto Xavier B. C. tiene 20 años, es soltero vive con sus padres, en el Cantón Ventanas Provincia de los Ríos. No Tiene hijos.  

Los miembros de la V.R.C. DIVINO NIÑO se encuentra ubicada en el recinto Estero Lindo pertenece al Cantón Ventanas, esta ventanilla de 12 miembros se dedica a las labores agrícolas en ciclo corto de siembra de maíz, arroz.

Fausto Xavier se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de maíz y arroz. Compra sus productos en  Agro Servicios San Jacinto y vende en el mismo lugar.

Solicita el crédito para sembrar maíz, y arroz, compra de insumos, semillas y pago de trabajadores. Con el apoyo del crédito le ayudaría económicamente para suplir sus necesidades. Enfrentar desafíos como las plagas y enfermedades y la variedad del clima. Su sueño es ser ingeniero 

Le gusta hacer deporte.
texts.en:
Fausto Xavier B. is 20 years old, he is single and he lives with his parents in Ventanas, a canton of the Los Ríos province. He has no children.

The V.R.C. Divino Niño (Divine Child Communal Bank) is located in the Estero Lindo precinct, located in the Ventanas canton; it is composed of 12 members who engage in short-cycle agricultural labor, growing crops like maize and rice.

Fausto Xavier se engages in agriculture, sowing maize and rice. He buys his products in the Agro Servicios San Jacinto and sells them in the same place.

The loan he is requesting will be used to sow maize and rice by buying supplies and seeds, and to pay his workers. The loan will help him economically, as thanks to it he will fulfill his needs, as well as face challenges such as pests, illnesses and climate changes. He dreams of becoming an engineer.

He likes practicing sport.

loans.use: To buy supplies and seed and to pay his workers.

loans.name: Raphael

texts.en:
Raphael is a married man with one child who is still too young for school. He owns a house that has piped water but not electricity. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

He has operated a retail shop for the past one year, selling to his local neighbors. Raphael faces a major challenge in high competition from other retail-shop operators. He hopes to expand and take another Kiva loan in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 he wants to purchase two boxes of sweets, juices, and dozens of bathing soaps for sale. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve his business.

loans.use: To purchase two boxes of sweets, juices, and dozens of bathing soaps for sale

loans.name: Firdavs

texts.en:
Firdavs B. lives in Kurgantyube, Tajikistan, where he is a successful businessman who has been selling a variety of eyeglasses over the past four years. A husband and father, he provides the family's only income. 

He has one vending location in the market where he sells his goods, and he wishes to expand his business by renting a second vending location. For this purpose he is requesting a loan of $1,500. This loan will increase his business sales, allowing Firdavs to diversify his merchandise and better provide for his family.  
        
                                                          
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi.
